Lack of face-to-face interaction - The absence of in-person interactions can lead to a sense of disconnection and isolation among team members, which can negatively impact morale and collaboration.
Difficulty in setting boundaries - With remote workers, it can be challenging to establish clear boundaries between work and personal life, leading to burnout or blurred lines between the two.

Technical issues - Remote employees may experience technical difficulties such as software compatibility issues, connectivity problems, or hardware failures, which can hinder productivity and collaboration.
Different work styles - Remote workers may have different work styles and habits, leading to conflicts and misunderstandings if not properly managed.
Lack of accountability - Without proper monitoring and check-ins, remote employees may feel less accountable for their work, leading to decreased productivity or poor performance.
